MAP_DESCRIPTION._text: In the absence of stress, the sigma factor σ24 is complexed with RssA and RssB in the inner membrane, but under envelope stress, misfolded proteins and lipoproteins appear in the periplasm. The lipoproteins release RssB from the complex RssB-rseA-σ24, and then a proteolytic cascade starts when DegS, bound to unfolded proteins, partially degrades the RseA protein in the  RseA-σ24 complex, producing the RseA-1-108 polypeptide that is cleaved by RseP, and the complex is released from the inner membrane. In the cytoplasm, HslUV or Lon can degrade RseA, releasing σ24, which can bind to core RNA polymerase to activate transcription of genes for maintaining cell envelope integrity. Another protease that also degrades RseA in the cytoplasm is ClpXP, but the protein SspB has to be bound to the RseA-1-108-RpoE complex. On the other hand, the rpoE gene, which forms part of the rpoE-rseAB operon, is induced by the TF CpxR, which is shown in the image as a submap in a gray box.

MAP_DESCRIPTION._text: In the absence of stress, the sigma factor σ24 is complexed with RssA and RssB in the inner membrane, but under envelope stress, misfolded proteins and lipoproteins appear in the periplasm. The lipoproteins release RssB from the complex RssB-rseA-σ24, and then a proteolytic cascade starts when DegS, bound to unfolded proteins, partially degrades the RseA protein in the  RseA-σ24 complex, producing the RseA-1-108 polypeptide that is cleaved by RseP, and the complex is released from the inner membrane. In the cytoplasm, HslUV or Lon can degrade RseA, releasing σ24, which can bind to core RNA polymerase to activate transcription of genes for maintaining cell envelope integrity. Another protease that also degrades RseA in the cytoplasm is ClpXP, but the protein SspB has to be bound to the RseA-1-108-RpoE complex. On the other hand, the rpoE gene, which forms part of the rpoE-rseAB operon, is induced by the TF CpxR, which is shown in the image as a submap in a gray box.

Another protease that also degrades RseA in the cytoplasm is ClpXP, but the protein SspB has to be bound to the RseA-1-108-RpoE complex. On the other hand, the rpoE gene, which forms part of the rpoE-rseAB operon, is induced by the TF CpxR, which is shown in the image as a submap in a gray box.

MAP_DESCRIPTION._text:
In the presence of ferric citrate, FecI activates transcription of genes that code for proteins necessary for  transport of ferric citrate.  
External ferric citrate binds to the protein FecA, causing a conformational change in this protein. After that, FecA is able to bind to TonB and FecR. On the one hand, FecA form a complex with  TonB, ExbD and ExbB, transporting the external ferric citrate to the periplasmic space. On the other hand, this complex binds to FecR, a protein that  binds to FecA and σ19 to stimulate the binding of σ19 to the RNA polymerase. Finally, the RNA polymerase-σ19 stimulates the transcription of the genes that code for proteins involved in the transport of ferric citrate from the periplasmic space to the cytoplasm.

MAP_DESCRIPTION._text:
In the presence of L-tyrosine, TyrR represses the transcription of genes that code for proteins necessary for synthesis and transport of L-tyrosine and L-phenylalanine. In the presence of L-phenylalanine, TyrR represses the transcription of genes that code for proteins necessary for synthesis of L-phenylalanine and activates the expression of a gene that encodes a transporter of L-tyrosine.
The TyrRL-tyrosine interaction also activates the transcription of mtr, a gene involved in the transport of L-tryptophan, and folA, a gene involved in the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate. Both molecules, L-tryptophan and tetrahydrofolate, are part of other Gensor units.
 The genes aroM and yaiA  are also regulated by TyrR in the presence of L-tyrosine, but their cellular functions  are unknown.

_text: In the presence of Fe
, Fur represses genes involved in transport and release of Fe
from siderophores and genes for biosynthesis and assembly of FeS clusters; in addition, it activates genes involved in Fe
storage and activates/represses genes that encode proteins that contain Fe
or a group heme as a cofactor. In the presence of the signal, Fur also regulates transcription of 9 TFs, as well as the σ
and σ

factors, and a regulatory sRNA,  RhyB, submaps of which are depicted as dark gray squares that can be expanded to see their corresponding Gensor Unit. In addition, Fur regulates genes that encode metal-binding proteins (other than Fe
) and other proteins that apparently have no direct relationship with Fe
or other metals.

(Overview)
In the presence of Fe
, Fur represses genes involved in transport and release of Fe
from siderophores and genes for biosynthesis and assembly of FeS clusters; in addition, it activates genes involved in Fe
storage and activates/represses genes that encode proteins that contain Fe
or a group heme as a cofactor. In the presence of the signal, Fur also regulates transcription of 9 TFs, as well as the σ
and σ

factors, and a regulatory sRNA,  RhyB, submaps of which are depicted as dark gray squares that can be expanded to see their corresponding Gensor Unit. In addition, Fur regulates genes that encode metal-binding proteins (other than Fe
) and other proteins that apparently have no direct relationship with Fe
or other metals.

MAP_GROUP._text: GUs related to metal utilization

MAP_DESCRIPTION._text: In the absence of stress, the sigma factor σ24 is complexed with RssA and RssB in the inner membrane, but under envelope stress, misfolded proteins and lipoproteins appear in the periplasm. The lipoproteins release RssB from the complex RssB-rseA-σ24, and then a proteolytic cascade starts when DegS, bound to unfolded proteins, partially degrades the RseA protein in the  RseA-σ24 complex, producing the RseA-1-108 polypeptide that is cleaved by RseP, and the complex is released from the inner membrane. In the cytoplasm, HslUV or Lon can degrade RseA, releasing σ24, which can bind to core RNA polymerase to activate transcription of genes for maintaining cell envelope integrity. Another protease that also degrades RseA in the cytoplasm is ClpXP, but the protein SspB has to be bound to the RseA-1-108-RpoE complex. On the other hand, the rpoE gene, which forms part of the rpoE-rseAB operon, is induced by the TF CpxR, which is shown in the image as a submap in a gray box.

MAP_DESCRIPTION._text: In the absence of stress, the sigma factor σ24 is complexed with RssA and RssB in the inner membrane, but under envelope stress, misfolded proteins and lipoproteins appear in the periplasm. The lipoproteins release RssB from the complex RssB-rseA-σ24, and then a proteolytic cascade starts when DegS, bound to unfolded proteins, partially degrades the RseA protein in the  RseA-σ24 complex, producing the RseA-1-108 polypeptide that is cleaved by RseP, and the complex is released from the inner membrane. In the cytoplasm, HslUV or Lon can degrade RseA, releasing σ24, which can bind to core RNA polymerase to activate transcription of genes for maintaining cell envelope integrity. Another protease that also degrades RseA in the cytoplasm is ClpXP, but the protein SspB has to be bound to the RseA-1-108-RpoE complex. On the other hand, the rpoE gene, which forms part of the rpoE-rseAB operon, is induced by the TF CpxR, which is shown in the image as a submap in a gray box.
